data.title: A Great Breakfast
data.text: This is a tiny hole in the wall restaurant with great food, wonderful cheery service and good pricing.  Been back a couple of times and it is our new go to breakfast spot.  Because it is small, you may nead to wait to get seated, but worth the wait.

data.title: Great Breakfast!
data.text: First time there and it reminded me of a great place to go in Greenwich Village in New York City. Great food and ambiance. Try the Mac & Cheese breakfast.

data.title: Great find
data.text: Great food.  Interesting selection .  Very good for both lunch and dinner.  Residential location would not expect such a good place to be located here.

data.title: Small location, but excellent food!
data.text: We came for a light lunch while we were travelling through the area. Looked briefly on Tripadvisor for recommendations, and it didn't disappoint. Although the place is smaller than we thought it would be, the food was great. We ordered the hummus, croissant french toast and the quiche. Everything was delicious. The customer service was very good, and the place looked clean as well. If we ever are in the area again, we definitely would make a trip back to eat here again.

data.title: Sweet Find!!
data.text: We stayed at the Hyatt down the street on a Saturday night and had some fun at the Sands. Sunday morning, I was googling places to eat breakfast and found found this spot! OMG!! What a sweet find!  The place is small but mighty. I mean like maybe 10 tables? But there is a counter and i am pretty sure you can get stun to go. Get there early so you get a table. The food is out of this world.  The menu is small and they have a few regular breakfast items but change it up with different specials often. My husband had some special skillet and I had eggs and bacon.  Everything was high quality and fresh!  The service was on point as well.  I wish we could've stayed for lunch! Definitely recommend.

data.title: amazing food & always a friendly face when you arrive.
data.text: The croissant french toast is amazing!! Any of the topping options are delicious. The service is always friendly as well.

data.title: Always great food
data.text: Food is always great here and the waitstaff is attentive and friendly,  One of us in our party always tries the specials and never disappointed.  the only problem with the place is the size - always have to wait for one of the very limited tables.  But do not be detered with the wait - always worth it for the food.

data.title: Friendly and good eats.
data.text: Place is small but the food is excellent and the service is great.  Great place to get breakfast all day.

data.title: Maybe we caught it on a bad day?
data.text: I was really looking forward to this visit based on other reviews. We went on a weekend morning. There is basically no place to park and we had to walk a fair amount to get there. The food was no better than so-so. I was disappointed. I had pancakes and my friend had a mac and cheese breakfast with meat.

data.title: #1 Breakfast Pick
data.text: Just finished a wonderful morning meal! Omelet with Gouda, apples and ham was amazing. Best buckwheat pancakes ever! Friendly and efficient service. Hats off to the chef!

data.title: Great food, friendly people
data.text: I came with friends who come frequently. The food was absolutely amazing and extremely affordable. The waitress was very friendly and the owner was great as well. Super busy and people were waiting for tables. Definitely would go back.

data.title: Breakfast
data.text: I have to say I was very impressed with the food as well as the coffee. Very filling and very tasty I love the Gouda cheese in my omelette and my wife love the mac & cheese for breakfast it was a awesome way to start off the day

data.title: Hip Breakfast Spot
data.text:
I dined at The People’s Kitchen with two family members for breakfast on a Sunday morning in mid-June 2016. The People’s Kitchen is open for breakfast and lunch daily. (The restaurant closes at 3:00 pm.) The People’s Kitchen does not accept reservations, so you may have to wait for a table on a busy day (the restaurant has placed a park bench outside where a few people can wait). The good news is that this is a casual breakfast and lunch joint, and your delay should not be longer than 30 to 45 minutes. If you are a smaller party (of one or two patrons), you can be seated faster, because there are many places that will accommodate you. However, if you are a larger party of three or more people, there are only two or so places where the staff can configure larger tables. Two-hour complimentary street parking is available. 

The People’s Kitchen, which opened in the fall of 2014, is located at the corner of North Street and Linden Street in Bethlehem, somewhat near the Downtown/Historic area. The restaurant occupies the spot that once held Theo’s Gyros, which is in a row-home in a somewhat residential area. The front of the restaurant contains the grill/open kitchen, followed by a lunch counter that seats about eight patrons. Three or four tiny tables for two are positioned against the wall and windows across from the counter, with another four tables in the rear, some of which can be pushed together to make larger configurations. (The maximum capacity of the restaurant is about 25 people at a time.) The staff performs all work in front of the diners (for example, cooking, food prep, dishwashing); there is no kitchen hidden in the back room. Space is at a premium; to reach the basement storage area, staff must open a floor panel behind the counter and descend right from the dining room/kitchen. The overall feel is a trendier version of a neighborhood luncheonette/diner. The walls are off-white, and feature framed black-and-white artwork and silhouettes with a bicycle theme; one wall also contains silhouettes of the Bethlehem Steel blast furnaces and a bicycle jump that highlight the flat-screen TV. It is easy to appreciate the decorative pressed-tin ceiling because of the many windows that allow light to reflect off the wood floors and wood counter top. Light jazz music provides a nice buzz. 

Bill Gruenewald owns the People’s Kitchen; he is a graduate of Liberty High School and Penn State, with a degree in hospitality management. Gruenewald also operates The Bolt & Key Café on the campus of Lehigh University, and he has been integral in opening the new Tavern at the Sun Inn.

The People’s Kitchen serves American cuisine. Our group of three shared three entrees: the breakfast macaroni and cheese (which is served in a small cast-iron skillet, with pasta, cheese, bacon, and potatoes; add an egg on top for an extra dollar), the shrimp and grits crepes (an abundance of large shrimp drizzled with barbecue sauce set atop crepes filled with grits), and one daily special, the chicken and waffles (shredded chicken in a cream gravy spread atop a thin sweet potato waffle). Everything was tasty and creative; however, although all entrees were priced the same, the portion size and heartiness varied greatly. The chicken and waffle was the least substantial, and the mac and cheese skillet was the most filling. More standard breakfast options like eggs, omelets, pancakes, and French toast are also offered on the smallish menu that arrives attached to a small clipboard. The lunch menu includes burgers, salads, and sandwiches, as well as some interesting-sounding specialties (such as crab bread, chicken tempura, hummus, and flatbread). Most of the entrée items on both the breakfast and lunch menus are priced in the $8 to $9 range. The People’s Kitchen does not serve alcoholic beverages. Service was extremely pleasant.

We enjoyed the unique breakfast dishes at the quaint hipster hangout, The People’s Kitchen.

data.title: Cozy Place
data.text: We found the staff both friendly and accommodating, when we visited there recently for breakfast.  I thoroughly enjoyed my buckwheat pancakes with bananas foster, and my companion was perfectly satisfied with his omelet! We will definitely plan to revisit there again!

data.title: Great spot
data.text: We arrived between breakfast and lunch so the server gave us both menus. Very friendly place. Was very busy but still received personalized service. The quiche of the day was very nice and the croissant French toast delicious as well. Definitely will return here when in the area.

data.title: Brexit special a must have
data.text: This small gem is awesome!  Today they have a special for 'Brexit' that meat eaters would love.  We asked if they could make it vegan and it was AMAZING.  If I wasn't so full I'd eat another!!!!

data.title: OK - was expecting more after all the raves
data.text: A small, narrow place in downtown Bethlehem, probably gets very crowded on weekends. I went with a few people from my running group on a Sunday morning after hearing a lot of good things about it. The place was busy but not jam packed. We sat at the counter and a waitress wordlessly handed us some menus. After a fairly long wait (hey, I've worked in restaurants before and did so for many years...I GET that sometimes you have to wait, but this was a long wait) the waitress returned and stood in front of us with her pad and pencil in hand, staring at us blankly. Obviously we were supposed to give her our order but we all found it pretty rude that a "good morning" or a "hello" wasn't even offered. After wordlessly taking our orders she walked off again. It took a while to get our drinks and the general feeling we got was that she was just having a VERY bad day. When the food arrived I found it OK but nothing special. I'd heard an awful lot about how unique the menu but my breakfast was pretty run of the mill. The other people seemed to feel similarly, one of our party thought his was REALLY good, but the rest of us were just sort of "meh" about the whole thing.

data.title: Amazing
data.text: Came on for the Mac and cheese skillet breakfast and ended up getting up 3 dishes and sharing because it was all so good. Meeting the chef was a treat and the service was super. They can tweak any dish to your asking and can make smaller portions so you can have more than one dish. Super place.

data.title: Cool vibe. Good food
data.text: Nice and friendly neighborhood restaurant. Had the geflugel chicken salad sandwich with a delicious multigrain ciabatta. Irish turkey sandwich was good but on the small side. Cucumber salad was tasty. Breakfast menu looked good. Reasonable prices.

data.title: 2nd visit and was not disappointed
data.text:
We were here earlier in the year for brunch and came back for breakfast. Last time it was just the 2 of us this time we had a group of 4. I had an omelette with pork roll, pepper jack cheese and onions (homemade cinnamin raisin bread) and the rest of the group had quiche (prosciutto, tomato and onion, Monte Cristo with berry compote and another omelete (spinach, ham and onion). 

It was packed and we had to wait about 15 minutes which wasn't bad. Service was excellent and friendly.
